title: Neighbours say 'Jeremy Kyle contestants' are making their lives 'hell' on estate
text:

Residents living in a crime-ridden housing estate described their neighbourhood as a "Jeremy Kyle contestants central" and say they have taken matters into their own hands.

There has been a recent spike in crime at Victoria Dock estate in Hull, with wheelie bins being set on fire and garden furniture being stolen and thrown into the river - with most of the crime happening in the early morning or late at night.

Neighbours say they are fed and claim enough is not being done by Humberside Police.

Some have installed security cameras and formed their own group to patrol the streets at night.

Ashley Jennings, who lives on the estate, said of the recent crimes: "We're all fed up of it, it's causing me and my family great distress, along with my neighbours.

(Image: Hull Daily Mail / MEN Media)

"I've installed safety cameras covering both mine and my neighbours gardens and there are a chosen few of us walking dogs later than usual to keep the crime rate down on the dock.

"We're going out of our way to ensure these things that are happening are kept down to a minimum."

Mr Jennings, originally from Hessle, moved to the area to be closer to family and the city centre.

He said "something needs to happen" about the current situation and warned residents will not hold back from arresting anyone caught engaging in criminal activity.

(Image: Hull Daily Mail / MEN Media)

"We go out making sure the streets are as safe as can be on the dock for our children's sake," he said.

"If we catch anyone misbehaving or doing something untoward we will be making a citizens arrest until the police come and take over. It's just too much."

Another man, who does not want to be named, said he regrets his recent move to the area.

He said: "After reading what's going on round here, I'm starting to regret it.

"It appears to be Jeremy Kyle contestants central."

(Image: Jon Corken/Grimsby Live)

Marilyn Leeson, who has been living in the area for 13 years says she's lucky to not be directly affected but she knows people who are.

"I think most people have had enough," she said.

Inspector Tony Towse, who heads the Hull East Neighbourhood Team at Humberside Police, said officers are "aware of the concerns from our community regarding crime and disorder in the Victoria Dock area of Hull".

"We treat all reports seriously and the Hull East Neighbourhood Team are working in the Victoria Dock area to prevent further issues and tackle those responsible," he said.

"I want to stress that people should not take action themselves but to call us immediately so we can deal with incidents."

Police are encouraging anyone to report neighbourhood crime or issues by calling 101. You can also call Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.
description: Wheelie bins have been set on fire and garden furniture has been stolen and thrown into the river at Victoria Dock housing estate in Hull
